summary: autophagy has no measurable role in vacuolar escape and intracellular growth in primary cultured bone marrow derived macrophages deficient for autophagy (atg5/). however, we provide evidence that the pore forming activity of the cholesterol-dependent cytolysin listeriolysin O (LLO) can induce autophagy following infection by L. monocytogenes. Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive, facultative intracellular, food-borne pathogen. it causes severe disease in pregnant and immunocompromised hosts. the intracellular life cycle of L. monocytogenes has been described in detail. autophagy is a mechanism by which cytoplasmic components, including long-lived proteins and damaged organelles, are enveloped within specialized double-membrane-bound vesicles. it has been hypothesized that basal levels of autophagy occur continuously inside of cells [20] an increase in autophagic activity can be stimulated by amino acid starvation, hormone signaling, cytokines, TLR stimulation and immunity related GTPases. authors of this study did not observe that wild-type L. monocytogenes grew better in atg5 / MEFs than in wild-type MEFs. however, the role of Atg5 in the control of wild-type L. monocytogenes replication remains controversial. re-evaluated the hypothesis that primary macrophages use autophagy as a defense against invading L. monocytogenes. either autophagy has no role in control of L. monocytogenes replication or that an as yet undiscovered bacterial virulence factor effectively circumvents autophagy. autophagy is induced by wild-type, actA, plcAB but not by hly or heat-killed L. monocytogenes.
